resources.string: What happened before the rumination started?
How did you feel at the time?
How long did the rumination last?
Record if you are ruminating now to continue.
Answer how long your rumination lasted.
Record if the rumination was helpful.
Record if the rumination made you feel better.
Recall the rumination you logged before. Thinking back on it...
Start a countdown timer, etc etc, say bessie bessie besssie bessie bessie

string-array.name: intro_titles
string-array.item: Meet Bessie
Bessie is our friend

string-array.name: pun_bank
string-array.item: ru-MOO-nation? udderly unfun!
MOO-ve worries along
improve your MOO-od
lasso good thoughts
stampede over rumination
re-MOO-ve worries
hay-nt time for worries
chew on this idea
my beef is with worrying
field rumination
fence in rumination
let bessie figure it out
ok to say "no MOO-ore"
herd about worry practice?
let thoughts range free
hoof it towards happiness
empty your fourth stomach

string-array.name: intro_content
string-array.item: People (like cows) are creatures of habit.
They live their lives, doing, thinking, feeling…
But, sometimes, when you think about something…
And then you think about it again…
And again…
And after all that thinking you start to feel worried…
Or stressed…
That’s when you know you’re ruminating.
Rumination can be very difficult to manage.
We’ll show you a few basic strategies on how to help with this.
Now… let’s begin.

string-array.name: didactic_content1
string-array.item: Distract with books, movies, magazines, museums, a busy street or bustling park. Force yourself to take these aspects of life or culture in even if you don’t feel like it. Once you are involved your mind has a chance to take another path.
Repeat the saying: “Grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change; change the things I can and wisdom to know the difference.”
Repeat a comforting phrase, an affirmation, a prayer, a poem or a song to yourself.

Exercise or walk. Moving your body can move the content in your head. Notice aspects of nature or humanity that are larger than your conundrum. Try to focus on what is outside of you rather than inside of you.

If you are “catastrophizing” or “awfulizing,” think of all the times you were sure a horror would happen and it didn’t. Turning a hysterical assumption into an objective assessment can take away pain and calm you. Write down what you fear, the worst thing that can happen, and then write down three more positive outcomes. Try to figure out what is most realistic. Try to be measured.

string-array.name: didactic_content2
string-array.item: Count your blessings instead of sheep, in the words of composer Irving Berlin. Research shows that a grateful person is a happy person.
Listen to music that has meaning for you or provides comfort, from your childhood or current times. Get swept up. Sing, dance or clean the car with the radio blasting Rolling Stones. Whatever.
Listen to radio programs that tells compelling stories about people who have undergone unusual struggles and triumphs. Watch a comedy channel.
Make arrangements to meet a good friend who can be relied upon to have a sensitive response or to make you laugh.
Trade heaviness for lightness even if that somehow feels wrong or unnatural or strange.

string-array.name: didactic_content3
string-array.item: Re-write the narrative. Sometimes if we can find a way to soften the story, minimize the blows, tell ourselves that the injury is really not going to damage us, it restores a sense of empowerment and equilibrium. It also removes power from the perpetrator.
Say, “Don’t think, don’t think, don’t think…” and then DO something: cook, scrub, fix, run, go somewhere and be around other people. Do a small project.
Gear up into high action: Accomplish more that you think you can, want to, or than you need. Get five things done instead of three. It might give you a rush. Get a little manic, in a good way.
Think about someone you know who is suffering and feel compassion. Call them or send them a message.

string-array.name: didactic_content4
string-array.item: Take a boxing class if meditation does not work for you. Some people need to punch it out. My friend Betty wears pink boxing gloves to support breast cancer research.
Don’t hang out with a demon filled head.

string-array.name: didactic_content5

resources.string: CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS wizard_one ( _id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, attempted_stop_method VARCHAR, duration INTEGER, emotion VARCHAR, wizard_one_timestamp INTEGER, rumation_content VARCHAR, rumination_isOver BOOLEAN, rumination_termination_cause VARCHAR, trigger VARCHAR)
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS profile ( _id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, concerns VARCHAR, help_frequency INTEGER, profile_timestamp INTEGER, ruminating_lately BOOLEAN)
What have you been ruminating about?
How often would you like help?
Choose how long you wish to ruminate
tell bessie what is on yr mind
